title: Science Vs: Organic Food - What’s the Real Difference?
summary: Examines the science behind claims that organic food is healthier, tastier, or better for the environment. Separates real benefits from marketing myths.
utterances: Organic food costs more, but are the health benefits real?
Pesticide residues are far lower than most people think.
Taste is subjective—but does science back it up?
transcript: Host Wendy Zukerman brings in nutritional scientists and farmers to discuss the real evidence on organic vs. conventional produce, exploring environmental footprint and health data.

title: Science Vs: Fracking - Earthquake or Solution?
summary: Dissects the controversy around fracking—its effects on earthquakes, groundwater, and the role it plays in energy policy.
utterances: Fracking is blamed for everything from earthquakes to pollution.
How risky is it really?
Can it ever be made safe for communities?
transcript: Geophysicists and environmental policy experts weigh in on seismic activity, new research, and whether fracking deserves its bad reputation.

title: Science Vs: Climate Change - How Do We Know?
summary: Breaks down the scientific evidence proving climate change and reviews the most common denialist arguments.
utterances: Climate models are better than people think.
So what exactly is causing global warming?
Sea level data doesn’t lie.
transcript: IPCC contributors and notable climatologists debunk denial myths, with a focus on ocean temperatures, weather patterns, and future projections.

title: Science Vs: Vaccines - Do They Cause Autism?
summary: Directly tackles the vaccine/autism myth by looking at major studies, medical fraud, and the real risks of vaccine hesitancy.
utterances: Dozens of studies have tested the link—what do they say?
Why did the myth gain traction, and who’s responsible?
Vaccination rates affect everyone, not just children.
transcript: Guests include global health leaders and parents who discuss how misinformation took hold and how science eventually won out.

title: Science Vs: Superfoods - Is Kale Really a Superhero?
summary: Puts common superfoods—kale, quinoa, acai—under the magnifying glass. Are they really miracle foods, or just hype?
utterances: Is kale truly better than iceberg lettuce?
Superfoods appear in the news every year.
Nutrient density matters, but context is key.
transcript: Science writers, nutritionists, and chefs discuss nutrient metrics, food fads, and the truth about what ‘super’ really means for your health.

title: Science Vs: Detox - Fact or Fantasy?
summary: Detox diets and cleanses are everywhere, but do they actually work or is it all pseudoscience? Science Vs dives into the evidence behind popular detox trends.
utterances: Juice cleanses claim to remove 'toxins' from your body—can they?
The liver already has a built-in detox system.
Are there any cleanses with proven health benefits?
transcript: Studies on detox diets and supplements reveal that our organs are quite good at removing toxins on their own, making most commercial cleanses unnecessary at best.

title: Science Vs: Paleo Diet - Caveman Craze
summary: Paleo diets are all the rage, but are they really backed by archaeological data and evolutionary science? Experts weigh in on meat, grains, and human history.
utterances: What did ancient humans actually eat?
Modern paleo has little to do with real prehistory.
Human bodies are adaptable, but is this a healthy fad?
transcript: Anthropologists and nutritionists explore what true paleolithic diets looked like and how well modern health claims stack up.

title: Science Vs: GMOs - Danger or Dinner?
summary: Genetically modified organisms spark public anxiety. Science Vs looks at the safety of GMOs and why they're so controversial.
utterances: GMOs are claimed to cause cancer, allergies, and more.
Independent science says something different.
How do they impact farming and the environment?
transcript: Leading life scientists explain rigorous evaluations for genetically modified crops and why so many fears are not supported by research.

title: Science Vs: Gluten - Should You Go Free?
summary: Is gluten really as dangerous as the hype suggests? This episode explores celiac disease, gluten sensitivity, and the truth behind wheat panic.
utterances: Gluten-free diets exploded in popularity.
Only a tiny fraction truly have celiac disease.
Are there hidden benefits or risks for the rest of us?
transcript: Gastroenterologists clarify the seriousness of celiac vs. gluten sensitivity, and whether gluten-free is healthier for everyone.

title: Science Vs: Salt - The Truth About Sodium
summary: Are you eating too much salt? Is sodium the real villain in heart disease? Science Vs reviews studies and expert opinions on salt intake.
utterances: Salt is essential—but how much is too much?
Medical journals reach different conclusions.
Blood pressure and diet guidelines are constantly evolving.
transcript: Nutrition researchers break down global salt studies and why recommendations differ, plus public health implications.

title: Science Vs: Meditation - Magic or Myth?
summary: Meditation is prescribed as a fix for everything from stress to depression—does it work, and if so, for whom?
utterances: Meditation can change brain structure—true or oversold?
Benefits are real, but often modest.
Who should meditate, and who maybe shouldn't?
transcript: Psychologists and neuroscientists discuss the cognitive and emotional impact of meditation, separating hype from data.

title: Science Vs: Juice Cleanses - Healthy or Hype?
summary: Juice cleanses are a wellness trend, but do they help or harm your body? Science Vs interviews doctors and nutritionists.
utterances: Juicing is good for vitamins, but bad for sugar.
Cleanses may do more harm than good.
Your liver and kidneys are your real detox machines.
transcript: Doctors debunk the myth that juice cleanses detoxify your system, and highlight risks like blood sugar spikes.

title: Science Vs: Placebo - The Power of Belief
summary: Explores the placebo effect—how powerful are sugar pills, and why does our brain respond?
utterances: Sugar pills work, but how and why?
Belief itself can trigger real brain chemical changes.
What limits the placebo effect?
transcript: Medical historians trace the rise of placebo-based treatments and new neuroscientific findings on expectation and response.

title: Science Vs: Hypnosis - Hype or Help?
summary: Is hypnosis real, or just a stage act? The science of altered states, therapy, and medical hypnosis for pain.
utterances: Most people can be hypnotized to some degree.
Medical hypnosis is effective for certain pain and anxiety.
It's not mind control, but suggestibility matters.
transcript: Therapists reveal what works and what doesn't in clinical hypnosis, plus who is most susceptible and why.

title: Science Vs: ESP - Can You Really Read Minds?
summary: Science Vs examines the research on extrasensory perception, mind reading, and psychic powers.
utterances: Studies on ESP date back decades.
No one can prove true psychic ability.
Why do so many still believe?
transcript: Parapsychologists and skeptics debate the best data, and why psychic claims attract ongoing interest.

title: Science Vs: Homeopathy - Healing or Hoax?
summary: Homeopathy remains popular, but is there any science to support it? Examining the evidence beyond anecdotes.
utterances: Homeopathy uses extreme dilutions of ‘remedies’.
Is anything in there besides water?
Clinical trials show little beyond placebo.
transcript: Pharmacologists and health regulators discuss regulation, case studies, and why homeopathy appeals to so many.

title: Science Vs: Supplements - Magic Pills?
summary: Vitamins and dietary supplements are a billion-dollar industry, but do most people benefit?
utterances: Most supplements aren't needed except in deficiency.
Overuse can do more harm than good.
Regulation and quality vary widely.
transcript: Doctors and nutrition experts discuss benefits for specific populations vs. hype and placebo in the general public.

title: Science Vs: Cold and Flu - Fact vs Fiction
summary: Do vitamin C, zinc, or chicken soup really fight colds? Science Vs examines folk cures, viral spread, and what actually helps.
utterances: Most cold remedies are comfort, not cure.
Viruses mutate too fast for lasting immunity.
Prevention beats treatment every time.
transcript: Epidemiologists break down cold and flu research, and the real prevention strategies (handwashing, sleep, vaccines) that actually work.

title: Science Vs: Mindfulness - Miracle or Fad?
summary: Mindfulness meditation promises big health benefits—but do studies support the hype, and who actually benefits most?
utterances: Mindfulness helps stress but won’t cure all ills.
Not everyone is equally responsive.
Clinical evidence is still evolving.
transcript: Behavioral therapists, neuroscientists, and critics discuss the value and limits of mindfulness practices in therapy.

title: Science Vs: Energy Drinks - Boost or Bust?
summary: Breaks down the science on caffeine, sugar, and supplement effects in popular energy drinks.
utterances: Energy drinks spike both caffeine and sugar intake.
High doses can be dangerous, especially for youth.
Is there any edge for athletes?
transcript: Toxicologists and sports doctors review ingredient lists, overdose risks, and lasting effects of energy drinks.
